messages.content:
I don't think there's a better way. The only piece of `safeTransferFrom` verification you could skip is checking the approval of the `from` address so it wouldn't save you that much. Trying to emit a single event with an array of recipients wouldn't be great as you wouldn't be able to filter for a particular address.

Fair amount of downside for very little upside (which is offset by cheap gas prices)

>  Trying to emit a single event with an array of recipients wouldn't be great as you wouldn't be able to filter for a particular address.

I also wouldn't do that as it is not standard and other dapps wouldn't catch the transfers

`approval` does not work for Plasma tokens.

If you use the PoS system, `approval` works similar to Ethereum
@TheKeiron
Thanks for the reply - so is it possible to get a smart contract to spend on behalf of a user on the POS system?

The polygon devs said that the user cannot approve a contract to spend on behalf of the user because the approval related functions are overridden to revert https://github.com/maticnetwork/contracts/blob/master/contracts/child/ChildERC20.sol

messages.content: I'm working on an ERC721 contract that mints on Polygon/Matic, but this means the NFTs will only exist on Matic; does anyone have any examples/pointers on what functions are required inside the ERC721 contract on layer 1 to allow the bridge to mint NFTs on L1? The docs only have about NFTs being "locked up" in the bridge when they are brought to L2, not about bringing them into existence when they only exist on L2 and you want to bring them to L1
i have the same issue

Hi everyone, nice to meet you.
I have a question in contract verify.
In ethereum and bsc, I used truffle verify using etherscan api key.
In matic network, I just deployed smart contracts to mainnet, but not sure how to verify them.
Please help me if anyone knows how to verify contracts using truffle.

I actually got an answer from the matic telegram chat, there's existing examples on the POS portal 

This is for the L1 side (ethereum):
https://github.com/maticnetwork/pos-portal/blob/master/contracts/root/RootToken/DummyMintableERC721.sol

And this is the matic/polygon L2 side:
https://github.com/maticnetwork/pos-portal/blob/master/contracts/child/ChildToken/ChildMintableERC721.sol

Note these examples bring both the token and the metadata (which i actually asked about earlier and never got pointed to!) if you don't need the metadata to be migrated too look at DummyERC721.sol/ChildERC721.sol

Hi guys. Complete newbie question - are all smart contract on the polygon network written in solidity? Thanks! 🙏

Probably yes but the more accurate answer is that they all target the Ethereum virtual machine. Solidity generates bytecode that runs in the Ethereum VM, but there are also a few alternative programming languages that can also generate Ethereum VM bytecode.
